channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Strong Earthquake Rattles Spain and Morocco
item.description: The temblor caused some material damage in southern Spain and northern Morocco, although no deaths or injuries were reported.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Opposition Groups in Moldova Unite to Protest New Government
item.description: More than 15,000 people demonstrated on Sunday after a new prime minister, Pavel Filip, was named to lead the country’s third government in a year.
item.dc:creator: KIT GILLET

item.title: E.U. Ministers Spar as Bloc’s Promise of Free Movement Wavers
item.description: The question hanging over a meeting is whether the bloc can agree on a collective approach to limit the influx of migrants and avoid an every-country-for-itself scramble.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Migrants on Monday at a camp in the northern Greek village of Idomeni, near the Macedonian border.

item.title: Palestinian Assailants Are Killed After Knife Attack on 2 Israeli Women
item.description: The attack, in which one of the women was critically wounded, was the third inside a West Bank settlement in eight days.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Global Health: Deforestation Threatens Pygmies, Study Finds
item.description: The first scientific census of the African population finds that there are nearly one million in communities threatened by encroaching societies.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vumi Swacse in a pygmy village outside Goma in the Democratic Republic of Congo in 2006. Researchers have created the first scientific estimate of Africa’s pygmy population.

item.title: U.N. Envoy for Syria Says Peace Talks Will Begin Friday
item.description: The envoy, Staffan de Mistura, said the talks in Geneva, aimed at a general cease-fire, would be “uphill” and declined to identify who was invited.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: A fighter from Army of Islam, the foremost rebel group in Damascus that fiercely opposes both the regime and ISIS, on Saturday.

item.title: China to Expel Swedish Human Rights Advocate
item.description: The Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Peter Jesper Dahlin, held this month on charges of violating security laws, had made “a full and frank confession.”
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:credit: Jonah M. Kessel/The New York Times
item.media:description: Peter Jesper Dahlin, a rights group organizer from Sweden, in Beijing in 2014. He was detained by the Chinese government in early January.

item.title: Dispatch From Dakar: ‘Mom, Did You Get Kidnapped?’
item.description: Dionne Searcey continues to chronicle her adventures in Senegal, where she moved her family and works as The Times’s West Africa bureau chief.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY
item.media:credit: Dionne Searcey for The New York Times
item.media:description: License papers, with a bullet hole, that Anthelme Djibril found in the glove box of his motorbike after the attack outside the Splendid Hotel in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso.

item.title: Henry Worsley, British Explorer Trying to Cross Antarctic Alone, Has Died
item.description: Mr. Worsley abandoned his 1,000-mile trek only 30 miles from his goal after suffering from exhaustion and dehydration.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER
item.media:description: Prince William, left, with the explorer Henry Worsley at Kensington Palace in London in October. Mr. Worsley died after trying to cross the Antarctic alone and without support.

item.title: Chinese Journalist Seeking Refuge in Thailand Disappears
item.description: There has been no news from Li Xin since Jan. 11, and his wife and others fear that Thai officials secretly turned him over to the Chinese authorities.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Li Xin, a Chinese journalist who has been missing since January, in New Delhi in November.

item.title: Letter From Europe: Study Finds Children of Immigrants Embracing ‘Frenchness’
item.description: But the landmark study also found persistent discrimination against the so-called visible minorities in France, mainly those of African origin.
item.dc:creator: CELESTINE BOHLEN
item.media:description: Muslims outside a mosque in Paris in November. Among the most troubling findings of a new French study is the lack of social mobility among the offspring of non-European immigrants.

item.title: Corsico Journal: Italian Town, Scrutinizing School Meals, Faces Cries of Bean Counting
item.description: The mayor, seeing that Corsico had a debt of over a million euros in unpaid lunch fees, decided that children whose parents had not paid would not be allowed to eat cafeteria-prepared meals.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anita Cimino owes more than 2,000 euros, or $2,160, in lunch bills. She said she was trying to work out a payment plan with the city.

item.title: Protesters in Haiti Demand That President Quit
item.description: One day earlier, officials had bowed to widespread civil unrest and postponed a single-candidate presidential runoff election that was to be held on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: FRANCES ROBLES
item.media:description: A vehicle burned after an opposition rally in Port-Au-Prince, Haiti, on Friday.

item.title: Airbus to Start Talks With Iran About Buying New Jets
item.description: The orders, likely to be partly financed with loans from European export-credit agencies, could be announced as early as this week, an official said.
item.dc:creator: NICOLA CLARK
item.media:description: An Airbus plane from the Iranian private airline Mahan Air in 2015. Iran is looking to place orders for more than 100 European-made aircraft.

item.title: African Economies, and Hopes for New Era, Are Shaken by China
item.description: Plunging prices are revealing how much nations, hailed in recent years as perhaps having outgrown their roots in raw materials, still depend on those commodities.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:description: South Africa’s currency, the rand, fell to record lows this month after China announced that imports from Africa plunged nearly 40 percent in 2015.

item.title: Terrorism Charges in Bangladesh for 14 Men Deported From Singapore
item.description: A group of men deported on suspicion of involvement with militant networks were charged, though Bangladesh said there was no evidence that they were planning an attack.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK

item.title: French Jews Fear a New Strain of ISIS-Inspired Anti-Semitism
item.description: The third attack on a Jew in Marseille since October — this time by a radicalized teenager who tried to decapitate a teacher — has evoked old fears in France.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: Benjamin Amsellem survived an attack by using his Torah.

item.title: In Portugal, Voters Pick Center-Right President
item.description: The new president, Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa, won 52 percent of the votes, with 98 percent counted.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: China Deepens Its Footprint in Iran After Lifting of Sanctions
item.description: The countries’ strategic pact gives China a western gateway to Middle East markets, and has saved Iran from international isolation and economic ruin.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: China’s president, Xi Jinping, left, with his Iranian counterpart, Hassan Rouhani, in Tehran on Saturday.

item.title: Yarrabah Journal: Aboriginal Brass Band Offers Burst of Hope in a Bleak Community
item.description: In its own modest way, a band created during a time of Aboriginal oppression is helping to heal deep racial wounds in Australia.
item.dc:creator: CLARISSA SEBAG-MONTEFIORE
item.media:credit: Andrew Quilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Men fishing at Wungu Beach in Yarrabah, Australia, recently.
